text:
When Mio was pivoting from enterprise to self-service, we created a Typeform for  waitlist. Embedded to all our blog posts then kept them updated via email.

It was about a 3 month period and we got nearly 1,000 sign ups, of which over 66% converted.

text:
If you could give us more *specifics*, we’d be able to provide more specific ideas.

Some questions I’d be asking myself when doing this are:

• What do we want our outcome to be? 
    ◦ Do we have any specific numbers we’re trying to hit within a certain timeframe?
• When are we launching?
• How’s finding PMF looking?
    ◦ Who do we sell to?
    ◦ Where do our customers learn about new products & solutions?
• What does our sales-motion look like? 
    ◦ Is it self-serve, sales-heavy, etc?
• What do my resources look like (people, budget, etc.)?

specifics

Is it self-serve, sales-heavy, etc?
What do my resources look like (people, budget, etc.)?

text:
Thanks everyone. You've all been really helpful!

For more context, this is a credit-led digital bank serving individual customers. We're trying to gain up to 100k customers over the next 3 - 6 months, before launch.

root.text: Does anyone have any specific ideas on the best content strategy for a startup in its pre-launch phase (just taking pre-orders at the moment)?

elements.text: Does anyone have any specific ideas on the best content strategy for a startup in its pre-launch phase (just taking pre-orders at the moment)?

text: I’m out of my element with consumer fintech here, but based on your goals and who your target audience is, SEO is definitely not the best route. I’d focus on finding ways to generate demand on social and through earned PR.

elements.text: I’m out of my element with consumer fintech here, but based on your goals and who your target audience is, SEO is definitely not the best route. I’d focus on finding ways to generate demand on social and through earned PR.

You can sell content or drive new leads from existing work. You can learn more here → <https://fyrii.com/> and get 3 months free with the code `Superpath-f373e65`

Agreed with <@U01P13NTGG6> here!

SEO isn't like a faucet you can turn on and off, it's a long term strategy that builds over time. It's unlikely that investing in content right now will net you hundreds of thousands of sign ups within three months 

However, I will note that Fintech is an _incredibly_ competitive niche, so I would recommend that you invest in growing E-A-T and content now, but supplement that with additional marketing efforts to build your base.

text:
Personal finance is really competitive in terms of SEO, but there are certainly a lot of topics you could rank for if you're putting a lot of effort into that over time. However, I probably agree with Skyler & Callahan that if your goal is that many customers in that timeframe, SEO isn't going to get you there — it's going to take 6+ months to build significant traffic, and even then, you're talking more about email list signups than people who are going to sign up for a new account.

Maybe talk to a PR or social agency about the most ideal way to grow your account? I've got some great recommendations if you want to DM me for them!

elements.text:

Maybe talk to a PR or social agency about the most ideal way to grow your account? I've got some great recommendations if you want to DM me for them!

text:
I’m a big advocate of SEO for growth (our business model and the software we built revolves around SEO after all) but its efficacy really depends on how customers make buying decisions and what stage a company is in. But Content ≠ SEO.

Allocating resources into SEO too early can sometimes be a waste of effort—especially if the company fails to find PMF, has to pivot, or can’t hit the milestones required to get to the next round of funding.

Even then, SEO won’t always be effective for every brand. For something like this, it can work in the long-run and should be started as soon as everyone is confident that the brand won’t fall into obscurity and just disappear one day. It will take awhile to build up the topical authority needed to drive results from inbound and will require a significant sustained investment of resources, but that’s okay, as your CAC from SEO will be significantly more sustainable vs your CAC from performance marketing.

But again, based on the current goals—I’d focus on generating buzz, cementing the brand as a key player, and generating demand.

elements.text:

Even then, SEO won’t always be effective for every brand. For something like this, it can work in the long-run and should be started as soon as everyone is confident that the brand won’t fall into obscurity and just disappear one day. It will take awhile to build up the topical authority needed to drive results from inbound and will require a significant sustained investment of resources, but that’s okay, as your CAC from SEO will be significantly more sustainable vs your CAC from performance marketing.

text: If a client asks you for a content strategy, would you start first with a content audit? I'm having a hard time wrapping my brain around providing a client a 3-6 month content strategy without doing a content audit first, but I've talked to other marketers out there and some say that they "look" at their current content and plan from there. My analytics brain can't NOT look at past performance, but i'm not sure how I should start with this. Any advice is welcome!

elements.text: If a client asks you for a content strategy, would you start first with a content audit? I'm having a hard time wrapping my brain around providing a client a 3-6 month content strategy without doing a content audit first, but I've talked to other marketers out there and some say that they "look" at their current content and plan from there. My analytics brain can't NOT look at past performance, but i'm not sure how I should start with this. Any advice is welcome!

text: Hey <@U02CVNB3X1T> An audit is a good place to start if you know what themes and topics they want to hit. I’d break it down between performance and content themes. If there’s a high traffic post, for example, that doesn’t really match they message they’re going after, you can move on from there. You can also look at source/medium to see where the traffic is coming from. Lots of traffic from organic social deserves a deeper look, for example. Hope it’s semi-helpful :smile:

elements.text: Hey

An audit is a good place to start if you know what themes and topics they want to hit. I’d break it down between performance and content themes. If there’s a high traffic post, for example, that doesn’t really match they message they’re going after, you can move on from there. text: <@U02G3SKQ4F5> Yeah - she told me that she never uses her website - and most of her business comes from referrals/LinkedIn and other types of outlets...which is kinda banana sandwich to me, as I would think you would build up your website. So i'm struggling to find out what content has "worked."

elements.text: Yeah - she told me that she never uses her website - and most of her business comes from referrals/LinkedIn and other types of outlets...which is kinda banana sandwich to me, as I would think you would build up your website. So i'm struggling to find out what content has "worked."

text: Yes, start with a content audit. Your first efforts likely will be to update their already published but underperforming content. Those are your quickest wins and can show the client strong results early. This is, of course, assuming her current site has content that is already published and ranking.

elements.text: Yes, start with a content audit. Your first efforts likely will be to update their already published but underperforming content. Those are your quickest wins and can show the client strong results early. This is, of course, assuming her current site has content that is already published and ranking.

I'm so used to doing a SEO audit, that a content audit is a little bit different...but also very similar. (if that even makes sense...)
